Effect of preparation method on the performance of porous RuOx/Co3O4 catalysts for 1, 2-dichloroethane oxidation Wei Deng Conceptualization Methodology Data curation Investigation Writing - original draft Writing - review & editing Ziye Jia Data curation Investigation Biao Gao Data curation Investigation Simin Zhu Data curation Investigation Dongqi Liu Writing - review & editing Funding acquisition * Limin Guo Supervision Writing - review & editing Funding acquisition * School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430074, China School of Environmental Science and Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan 430074 China School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Porous Co3O4 with high yield was synthesized through calcination from plate-like Co(OH)(OCH3). Then, a series of Co3O4 supported RuOx catalysts were prepared using three different loading methods, including homogeneous precipitation (HP), precipitation-deposition (DP), and wet impregnation (IM). Their physicochemical properties were investigated by various characterization techniques, and their performance for catalytic oxidation of 1, 2-dichloroethane (1, 2-DCE) was also evaluated. RuOx/Co3O4-HP possessed the most outstanding low-temperature reducibility, more oxygen vacancies, and surface active oxygen, correspondingly exhibited a better catalytic activity and lower selectivity of polychlorinated by-products. Moreover, RuOx/Co3O4-HP also presented an excellent performance for other types of hydrocarbons abatement. The stability test showed that the RuOx/Co3O4-HP showed highly stable activity for 1, 2-DCE oxidation, and the beneficial effect of water was further confirmed. Keywords Catalytic oxidation CVOCs 1, 2-dichloroethane RuOx/Co3O4 1 Introduction The removal of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) has been an urgent task worldwide because they are the main substances for environmental problems [1]. In recent years, more attention has been paid to chlorinated VOCs (CVOCs) due to their more toxicity and lower bio-degradability [2]. Catalytic oxidation is regarded as one of the most promising ways to eliminate or reduce the CVOCs emissions because of its high efficiency, low operating temperature, and more economically [3]. However, the development of catalysts with high activity, durability and selectivity to acceptable environmental products including CO2, H2O, and HCl is challenged [4]. Two different kinds of catalysts, such as supported noble metal and non-noble metal oxides, were widely reported [5,6]. Among them, supported noble metals such as Pt, Pd, and Rh often presented high initial activity, but they were susceptible to Cl poisoning deactivation and easy to persuade the formation of more toxic polychlorinated by-products, even dioxin [7]. However, it was noteworthy that Ru as an active component in the industrial process for the Cl2 production (Deacon Reaction: HCl + O2→Cl2 + H2O) was considered to be one of the most promising noble metals for catalytic combustion of CVOCs due to good chemical stability and the less formation of polychlorinated by-products [8]. By comparison, non-noble metal oxides possessed comparable activity besides low-cost and earth-abundance, such as the widely concerned CeO2 [9], MnOx [10,11], VOx [12,13], CrOx [14,15], and Co3O4 based catalysts. CeO2 presented high activity for CVOCs combustion but was easy to deactivate due to the inorganic Cl species deposit on active sites [16]. For MnOx-based catalysts, MnOx was activated into MnOClx that was regarded as the main active site for catalytic oxidation of CVOCs. However, it could be further chlorinated into the inactive MnClx under harsh reaction conditions [17,18]. Although VOx and CrOx based catalysts showed extremely high activity for CVOCs oxidation, their high toxicity and easy loss severely constrained their practical application [14,19]. As a typical non-noble metal oxide, Co3O4 had been demonstrated to be one of the most efficient catalysts for the total oxidation of hydrocarbons and CO due to its strong redox ability and abundant active oxygen species [20,21], meanwhile, which also showed high activity for CVOCs combustion and noticeable resistance to Cl-poisoning at high temperature (>300 °C) [22,23]. However, the high chlorination activity and the slow oxidation-reduction cycle of Co3O4 were tended to produce more toxic polychlorinated by-products and deactivate at low-temperature [24–26]. Thus, the enhancement of the stability at low-temperature and the inhibition of possible chlorination was critical for cobalt-based catalysts and some work had been reported. Lao et al. [27] found that the Co3O4 supported RuOx catalysts showed high activity for catalytic oxidation of chlorinated aromatics, which was associated with the generation of high active Ru-O-Co bonds and increase in the surface active oxygen species due to the replacement of Co3+ by Ru4+. Cao et al. [28] reported that the synthesized core-shell Co3O4@ZSM-5 catalysts using a microwave hydrothermal method presented an excellent CO2 selectivity and low by-products yield for dichloromethane combustion. Xu et al. [29] also found that 90 % conversion was observed on rare earth metal doping Co3O4 (CoCeYOx) at 256 °C for catalytic combustion of chlorobenzene, which also essentially reduced the generation of dichlorobenzene owing to the promoting of redox ability. However, the development of Co-based catalysts with preferable performances, such as better activity, durability and selectivity, for CVOCs oxidation is still desired. Moreover, the versatility of Co-based catalysts should be noticed because the organic pollutants in realistic industrial emissions normally consisted of several pollutants. Up to now, synergistic catalytic combustion purification of multi-component pollutants containing non-chlorinated hydrocarbons and CVOCs was not focused. The effects of non-chlorinated hydrocarbons on the behavior of CVOCs combustion, such as the selectivity of HCl and polychlorinated by-products, were rarely reported [30]. In this paper, porous Co3O4 as the support was firstly synthesized through a calcination-induced phase transformation of plate-like Co(OH)(OCH3) prepared by a solvothermal method using methanol as solvent, and then the supported RuOx (1.0 wt. %) catalysts were prepared by three different methods. Several technologies were conducted to study the physicochemical properties of porous Co3O4 and its supported RuOx catalysts. The effect of preparation methods on catalytic performance, including activity and polychlorinated by-products selectivity for 1, 2-dichloroethane oxidation, was comprehensively investigated. For the preferred RuOx catalyst, the stability and the influence of water vapor were further evaluated compared with Co3O4. Furthermore, catalytic oxidation of different pollutants and their multi-component pollutants with 1, 2-dichloroethane was also synergistically studied. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of porous Co3O4 and its supported RuOx catalysts The porous Co3O4 was thermally transferred from its plate-like precursor prepared by a solvothermal method using methanol as solvent [31,32]. In detail, appropriate amounts of Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O were added to 75 mL methanol solution under stirring with a molar concentration of 0.1 M·L−1. After the Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O was completely dissolved, the solution was transferred to an autoclave and then kept at 180 °C for 24 h. The plate-like precursor (Fig. S1) was collected by filtration and dried at 60 °C in an oven for 12 h. Finally, the as-obtained light pink powder was calcined at 400 °C for 4 h in an air atmosphere at a rate of 2 °C min−1 to produce porous Co3O4. The RuOx/Co3O4 catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation (IM), deposition precipitation using NaOH solution (2.0 wt. %) as precipitator (DP), and homogenous precipitation with urea hydrolysis (HP), respectively. The theoretical loading of Ru was 1.0 wt. % and the actual Ru loadings were listed in Table 1 . The detailed procedures were as following: (1) Wet impregnation method 2.0 mL RuCl3 (5.0 g/L Ru based, the same below) aqueous solution was added to 1.0 g Co3O4 and homogeneously mixed, then dried in an oven at 60 °C for 12 h followed by calcined at 400 °C for 4 h under static air in a muffle furnace. The prepared catalysts were denoted as RuOx/Co3O4-IM. (2) Deposition precipitation method 1.0 g Co3O4 and 2.0 mL RuCl3 aqueous solution was dispersed into 100 mL deionized water under stirring, then NaOH aqueous solution (2.0 wt.%) was added slowly to adjust the pH value to about 9.0. After being aged at room temperature for 2 h, the formed solid was filtered and washed with deionized water until pH = 7.0, then dried in an oven at 60 °C for 12 h followed by calcined at 400 °C for 4 h under static air in a muffle furnace. The prepared catalysts were denoted as RuOx/Co3O4-DP. (3) Homogenous precipitation method 1.0 g Co3O4, 0.5 g urea, and 2.0 mL RuCl3 aqueous solution were added to the 100 mL deionized water under stirring, then the mixture was stirred for another 4 h in an oil bath at 80 °C. After cooling down to room temperature, the precipitate was filtered and washed, dried in an oven at 60 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 400 °C for 4 h under static air in a muffle furnace. The prepared catalysts were denoted as RuOx/Co3O4-HP. 2.2 Characterizations The phase and structure of the catalysts were determined by using X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectra. The morphology and elements' distribution was observed using scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), scanning transmission electron microscopy (FE-S/TEM), transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), and EDS mapping. The surface component and oxidation state were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS). N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were carried out to obtain the specific surface area, pore size, and pore volume of the catalysts. The redox and acidic properties of catalysts were studied by H2-TPR and NH3-TPD, respectively. More details could be found in our previous report [24]. 2.3 Activity test Catalytic activities of catalysts for VOCs oxidation were tested in a quartz tube reactor with an inner diameter of 4 mm at atmospheric pressure. Feed stream was prepared by delivering liquid VOCs (1, 2-DCE or toluene) with a syringe pump (KDS 100, USA) and propane standard gas (metered by a mass flow controller) at a given concentration into a dry gas mixture composed of 10 % O2 and N2 balance. The injection part was electrically heated to ensure complete evaporation of liquid 1, 2-DCE or toluene, and 100 mg of catalyst (40–60 mesh) was used (GHSV was 60,000 mL g−1 h−1). The effects of GHSV on 1, 2-DCE conversion were investigated by changing the loading amount of RuOx/Co3O4-HP under the gas flow rate of 100 mL min−1. 3 vol. % water vapor (when used) was added by a bubbling method. The reactants and products were analyzed online by gas chromatography (GC, FULI, GC9790II, China) equipped with FID, TCD, and nickel converting equipment. The conversion was measured by the average value of three sampling analyses, and the carbon balance was up to 96 % or higher. Cl2 was detected by a chemical titration method as described in our previous work [24]. Both external and internal diffusion limitations were excluded by varying the particle size of catalysts and W/F (the ratio of catalyst weight to the total flow rate). More details could be found in Supplementary Materials. Usually, the mentioned mass transfer resistance was eliminated with a linear velocity higher than 7.0 cm·s−1 when the catalyst particle size was diminished to 40–60 mesh [13]. 2.4 Temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) The temperature-programmed surface reaction was conducted: the feeding containing 1000 ppm 1, 2-DCE and 10 % O2/Ar continuously flowed through 100 mg catalyst, was heated from 100 to 400 °C at the heating rate was 2 °C min−1 in a temperature controlled-reactor. 1, 2-DCE and products were analyzed online by mass spectrometer apparatus (Hiden HPR-20EGA, England). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization of catalysts XRD patterns of the as-synthesized precursor are shown in Fig. S1, whose diffraction peaks could be indexed to a structure of Co(OH)(OCH3) according to Zhu’s report [31]. As described, a typical esterification of acetate ligands driven by heating in the presence of methanol reaction of Co(CH3COO)2 + CH3O → Co(OH)(OCH3) + CH3CO2CH3 + H2O occurred during the solvothermal process and plate-like Co(OH)(OCH3) formed [32]. Moreover, the yield of the products was close to 100 % (as the residue solutions were colorless). As evidenced in Fig. S1 and Fig. S2, XRD patterns indicated that a spinel structure of Co3O4 (JCPDS No. 42-1467) was obtained after calcination [33]. After loading RuOx species, the crystal phase of Co3O4 was not obviously affected. The phases corresponding to RuOx species were not detected due to their high dispersion (Fig. 1 A). However, the diffraction peak at 36.9 ° shifted to the lower angle (Fig. 1A, inset), which was an indication of the doping of Ru3+/4+ species into the octahedron centers of the Co3O4 spinel structure because the ionic ratio of Ru3+/4+ (0.68 and 0.62 Å) was larger than Co3+ (0.61 Å) and led to the lattice expansion [34]. Meanwhile, the lattice parameter of Co3O4 increased from 8.082 Å to 8.088–8.093 Å after loading RuOx (Table 1), which further confirmed the incorporation of Ru3+/4+ into the lattice of Co3O4. Additionally, the crystalline size of all the samples was about 19 nm based on Scherrer equation applied for (311) at the 2θ angle of 36.9° (Table 1). Fig. 1.B further showed Raman spectra of Co3O4 and its supported RuOx samples. Five Raman-activated modes could be detected on the Co3O4. In particular, the main band at about 678 cm−1 corresponded to the A1g species in the O h 7 spectroscopic symmetry from octahedral sites (CoO6) and the band at about 190 cm−1 was assigned to the F2 g 1 symmetry from tetrahedral sites (CoO4). Meanwhile, the band located at about 477 cm−1was assigned to Eg symmetry and the bands at 521 cm-1 accompanied with 613 cm−1were assigned to the F2 g 2 symmetry [35]. With the adding of RuOx, no new bands appeared, but the intensity of the bands decreased and the position shifted to the low wavenumbers (Fig. 1B, inset), indicating that Ru species incorporated into the lattice of Co3O4. All the results were highly consistent with XRD results. The actual Ru content of all supported RuOx samples determined by ICP-AES was approximately 0.90 wt. % (Table 1), which indicated that Ru species could be effectively loaded by the adopted three methods. The textural properties, such as the specific surface area, average pore size, and pore size distribution, were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption as shown in Fig. 2 and Table 1. All the samples presented a type IV sorption isotherm with an H2-type hysteresis loop in the relative pressure range of 0.75–1.0, which confirmed the existence of mesopores (Fig. 2A). Meanwhile, the pore size distribution calculated from the adsorption isotherms branch based on the BJH model indicated that the mesopores' size was central at about 30 nm (Fig. 2B). Specific surface areas of Co3O4, RuOx/Co3O4-HP, RuOx/Co3O4-DP, and RuOx/Co3O4-IM were 19.0, 16.4, 16.1, and 18.0 m2 g−1, respectively. The loading of RuOx species slightly reduced the specific surface area due to the block of RuOx species into the pores. SEM images displayed that the as-synthesized Co(OH)(OCH3) precursors were composed of the plate-like nano-sheets (Fig. S1). After calcination, the porous Co3O4 was obtained due to the decomposition of organics. With the loading of RuOx species, the morphology of all the samples was still well maintained (Fig. S2), which was also well reﬂected by the results of N2 sorption isotherms. Furthermore, SEM (SE, secondary electron), TEM (DF, dark field), and TEM (BF, bright field) images of porous RuOx/Co3O4 were obtained from the FE-S/TEM system to directly investigate the morphology and porous structure of the synthesized catalysts (Fig. 3 ). As shown in Fig. 3, the pores with a wide size distribution were observed clearly on the synthesized samples. HRTEM further confirmed that the existence of these pores and their wide distribution (Fig. 4 ). However, it was difficult to find the RuOx species over all the porous RuOx/Co3O4 samples by TEM images because of their high dispersion or incorporation into the lattice of Co3O4. Moreover, STEM elemental mapping images in Fig. S3 revealed that the Co, O, and Ru were highly dispersed. The reducibility of Co3O4 and its supported RuOx samples were evaluated by H2-TPR and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . A typical two-step reduction was observed on Co3O4, which could be attributed to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ (centered at 306 °C) and Co2+ to metallic Co (centered at 380 °C), respectively [37]. With the addition of RuOx, all reduction peaks shifted to the lower temperatures and RuOx/Co3O4-HP presented the best reducibility (the lowest top temperature peak was at about 152 °C), which was attributed to that the Ru4+ replaced the Co3+ in the Co3O4 spinel structure, and two reduction processes involved: Ru4+-Co3O4 → Ru3+-CoO and Ru3+-CoO → Ru°-Co° [27]. In addition, an additional minor reduction peak below 100 °C was observed on the supported RuOx samples. It could be assigned to the reduction of RuOx nano-clusters [38,39], which was easily reduced to metallic Ru due to the high activity for H2 dissociation and thus could accelerate the reduction rate of RuOx/Co3O4 [27]. The activation energy via the Kissinger Equation (Ln (β/T2 max) = K+ (Ea/R) (1/Tmax), where Tmax is the top temperature for the peak, K is a constant, Ea is the activation energy, and R is the gas constant) was calculated based on the first reduction step from TPR profiles obtained by tuning heating rates (Fig. 5B and Fig. S4) [36]. The RuOx/Co3O4-HP undoubtedly presented the lowest value of 60.4 kJ mol−1, which implied the strongest low-temperature reducibility. Moreover, the overall H2 consumption was calculated and listed in Table 1. The loading of RuOx species resulted in a slight decrease of H2 consumption, which could be ascribed to the higher relative atomic mass of Ru or the presence of metallic state Ru. Fig. S5 presented NH3-TPD profiles of the synthesized catalysts to determine their acidic properties. Considerable acid sites could be detected on Co3O4. Two desorption peaks distributed before 250 °C and centered at about 400 °C appeared, which corresponded to the weak and moderate strong acid sites [40]. After the RuOx species was loaded, the shape of desorption profiles almost remained, but the peak area decreased, which corresponded to the decreasing of acid sites due to the coverage of RuOx species on Co2+/3+ or oxygen vacancies as Lewis acid sites [24,27], which were beneficial for the rupture of C-Cl bonds and the adsorption/activation of CVOCs [41–43]. Fig. 6 showed Co 2p, Ru 3p, and O 1s XPS spectra of Co3O4 and its supported RuOx catalysts. Co 2p XPS spectra could be fitted to the four peaks associated with Co3+ and Co2+, in detail, the peaks with binding energies in the range of 779.6–780.1 eV and a 2p3/2-2p1/2 splitting of 15.1 eV could be assigned to the octahedral Co3+, and the peaks with binding energy in the range of 780.9–781.4 eV and a 2p3/2-2p1/2 splitting of 15.5 eV corresponded to the tetrahedral Co2+ (listed in Table 1). Additionally, the satellite peaks located at 3.6–6.5 eV (Sa1) or 9.4 eV (Sa2) higher than 2p3/2 could be assigned to Co2+ and Co3+ respectively, and the third satellite peaks (Sa3) located at 803.3–804.2 eV (Fig. 6A) [44]. The ratio of Co2+/(Co2++Co3+) was estimated (Table 1) and the results indicated that the content of surface Co2+ increased as the loading of RuOx due to the reduction of Co3+ by Ru3+ or the Ru4+ occupied Co3+ site resulting in another one Co2+ ion formation [45]. Among all the supported RuOx samples, RuOx/Co3O4-HP possessed the highest Co2+, meaning more oxygen vacancies formed. Moreover, the lower shift in the binding energy of Co further confirmed the occurrence of an electron-transferring. The spectra of Ru 3p could be deconvoluted to three peaks at about 465.5, 463.5, and 462.0 eV, which were assigned to Ru6+, Ru4+, and Ru°, respectively (Fig. 6B) [46]. Meanwhile, the estimated ratio of Run+/ (Run++Ru°) was listed in Table 1 and RuOx/Co3O4-HP presented the highest value. For the spectra of O 1s, two deconvoluted peaks in the range of 528.9–530.0 eV and 531.0–531.4 eV could be determined (Fig. 6C), which was assigned to lattice oxygen species (Oα) and surface oxygen species (Oβ) including highly active oxygen species such as O2 − or O− [47]. The estimated ratio of Oβ/ (Oα+Oβ) based on the peak area indicated that more active oxygen species generated over supported RuOx catalysts, and RuOx/Co3O4-HP presented the highest ratio (Table 1). 3.2 Catalytic performance of porous Co3O4 and its supported RuOx catalysts Fig. 7 A presented the light-off curves of 1, 2-DCE oxidation over synthesized catalysts, and the corresponding T50/T90 (temperature for 50 % and 90 % conversion) was listed in Table 1. Considerable activity was detected on Co3O4 with the T50 and T90 were 322 and 375 °C, respectively. However, an obvious deactivation occurred in the range of 200−230 °C, which was consistent with most of reports about CVOCs oxidation on Co3O4 [24]. With the addition of RuOx species, the light-off curves of 1, 2-DCE oxidation shifted to lower temperatures, and the T90 of RuOx/Co3O4-HP was only 304 °C, which was much lower than that of the most reported values [11,48,49]. Meanwhile, the formation of trichloroethane as the main polychlorinated by-products was unavoidable for oxidation of 1, 2-DCE over Co3O4 and followed a classical electrophilic substitution mechanism. Over which, the maximum concentration was 60 ppm at 320 °C and then declined with the rise of reaction temperature due to the further oxidation of trichloroethane. After loading RuOx species, the formation of trichloroethane occurred at a lower temperature (about 200 °C), and the maximum concentration also decreased from 60 ppm for Co3O4 to about 35 ppm or lower. The generation of trichloroethane was usually considered to be related to adsorbed Cl species and Cl2, and TPSR results confirmed the effluence of Cl2 via the oxidation of adsorbed Cl species and formed at a higher temperature over Co3O4 (Fig. S6). The XPS and ToF-SIMS results showed that the Cl species easily deposited on the catalysts' surface during CVOCs oxidation and especially was captured by oxygen vacancy sites [50,51], which accounted for the formation of polychlorinated by-products as evidenced by previous reports [27,52]. The formation of trichloroethane could be through oxy-chlorination of DCE with adsorbed Cl species or chlorination of DCE with Cl2. However, the formation of Cl2 over Co3O4 only occurred above 300 °C, which indicated that the adsorbed Cl species was primarily responsible for the formation of trichloroethane (namely oxy-chlorination pathway). With the addition of RuOx species, the removal of adsorbed Cl species accelerated in the form of Cl2 (the lower Cl2 generating temperature, which reduced to about 260 °C). Thus, the formation of trichloroethane largely decreased. Meanwhile, the Cl2 selectivity was determined by a chemical titration method and disclosed in Fig. 7B. The formation of Cl2 shifted to a lower temperature from 300 °C for Co3O4 to about 260 °C for RuOx/Co3O4 catalysts. Moreover, the maximum selectivity of Cl2 (50.4 %) over Co3O4 was detected at 400 °C, while increased to about 61.0 % at 340 °C over supported RuOx catalysts. Additionally, the curves of CO2 yield showed in Fig. 7B indicated that 1, 2-DCE was almost wholly oxidized into CO2, and only a small amount of CO formed (<20 ppm) at a low-temperature range, which was also confirmed by TPRS (Fig. S6). Furthermore, the synthesized promising RuOx/Co3O4-HP also showed high activity for different pollutants oxidation, such as propane, toluene, dichloromethane, and chlorobenzene, with T90 could reach at before 310 °C under high GHSV of 60,000 mL g−1 h−1 (Fig. S7). The catalytic efficiency of Co3O4 and its supported RuOx catalysts for 1, 2-DCE oxidation was further compared based on the reaction rate at 220 °C, and the results were listed in Table 1. The apparent reaction rate over Co3O4 was about 0.05 μmol min−1 m-2, which exponentially increased with the addition of RuOx species, especially for the sample of RuOx/Co3O4-HP with excellent low-temperature reducibility. In detail, the reaction rate over RuOx/Co3O4-HP was 0.55 μmol min−1 m-2, which more than tenfold to Co3O4, and expectedly higher than 10 %Cr/TiO2 (0.051 μmol min−1 m-2 at 225 °C under GHSV of 40,000 mL· g−1 h−1) [48] and CrOx/MnCo3Ox (0.330 μmol min−1 m-2 at 225 °C with GHSV = 36,000 mL g−1 h−1) [53]. When combined with the XPS results, it could be found that the reaction rate was positively correlated with the ratio of Oβ/(Oα+Oβ), which indicated that the surface active oxygen species was a significant factor for the oxidation of 1, 2-DCE over porous RuOx/Co3O4 [27]. Sequentially, the effects of inlet 1, 2-DCE concentration and GHSV on the conversion of 1, 2-DCE over RuOx/Co3O4-HP were further investigated. It was clear that the conversion curves shifted to higher temperature with the increase of 1, 2-DCE concentration (Fig. S8), which could be attributed to the deficit of the active sites for 1, 2-DCE activation. Based on the reaction rate presented in Fig. 7C, RuOx/Co3O4-HP catalyst presented a similar reaction rate at a low-temperature range (below 260 °C), which did not depend on the concentration of 1, 2-DCE, suggesting that desorption of the products might be slow and was the rate-determining step. When the temperature was higher than 260 °C, Cl2 was generated according to the results of TPSR and chemical titration. The reaction rates showed a linear relationship with the concentration of 1, 2-DCE. Additionally, it could be found that the conversion of 1, 2-DCE over RuOx/Co3O4-HP reduced as the GHSV increased (Fig. 7D). The T50 and T90 of 1, 2-DCE oxidation at GHSV = 60,000 mL g–1 h–1 increased by 42 and 38 °C compared with that of at GHSV = 15,000 mL g–1 h–1. These results were expected, the residence time of 1, 2-DCE molecules on active sites reduced as the GHSV increased, which led to the decrease in the conversion of 1, 2-DCE. Totally, 1, 2-DCE was adsorbed/activated on acidic sites, then oxidized by oxygen species and finally to mainly form CO2, H2O, HCl, and Cl2. The deposited Cl species were the main reason for the formation of polychlorinated by-products. After loading the RuOx species, more active oxygen species were generated, accompanied by enhanced reducibility, thus presenting higher activity. Meanwhile, the formation of trichloroethane was largely retarded and the formation of Cl2 shifted to lower temperatures due to the high activity for Deacon Reaction [24,27]. As is well known, the real exhaust gas usually consisted of various kinds of VOCs, and the presence of different pollutants might have a significant impact on the performance of catalysts for targeted VOCs oxidation. Thus, it is meaningful to evaluate the catalystsʹ performance, including the activity and the behavior of by-products formation, to control multiple pollutants synergistically. Fig. 8 showed catalytic performance of RuOx/Co3O4-HP for synergistic catalytic oxidation of toluene or propane and 1, 2-DCE. The high activity for single toluene oxidation was observed, and the conversion of toluene could reach about 100 % at 220 °C. With the addition of 1, 2-DCE into the reaction system (Two contaminants: 500 ppm 1, 2-DCE and 500 ppm toluene), the conversion profile for toluene shifted to a higher temperature due to the deposit of Cl species from 1, 2-DCE oxidation on active sites. Meanwhile, the conversion of 1, 2-DCE was unstable, and the conversion profile shifted to the higher temperature before 250 °C, which could be ascribed to the competitive adsorption or oxidation between two molecules. Conversely, the conversion of 1, 2-DCE was accelerated at a high-temperature range (>260 °C), which could be ascribed to the promotion of Cl2 formation via Deacon Reaction or the increase in mobility of active oxygen formed on the RuOx cluster/nanoparticles during the reaction [54]. Correspondingly, trichloroethane was not detected for catalytic oxidation of two contaminants because of the presence of toluene as the hydrogen source. Meanwhile, the RuOx/Co3O4-HP displayed a similar catalytic behavior for catalytic oxidation of propane and 1, 2-DCE (Fig. 8 B). There still no trichloroethane was formed during the whole process for two contaminants oxidation. It should be noted that when propane and 1, 2-DCE co-feed, the conversion of 1, 2-DCE was much higher than propane at low-temperature range. As reported, the activation of C–H bonds was the issue key for propane oxidation, while the activation of C-Cl bands was prior for the CVOCs [55]. The bond energy of the C–H bond in the propane molecule (401.3 kJ mol−1) [56] is higher than that of the C-Cl bond in the 1, 2-DCE molecule (345.1 kJ mol−1) [57], thus the 1, 2-DCE might be easier to activate than propane. Totally, the synthesized RuOx/Co3O4-HP showed high activity for propane or toluene, 1, 2-DCE, and their mixture oxidation, which was considered to be a promising catalyst for catalytic oxidation of actual VOCs emissions. The stability of Co3O4, RuOx/Co3O4-HP, and RuOx/Co3O4-IM was comparatively investigated on the stream containing 1000 ppm 1, 2-DCE, 10 % O2 and a balance of N2 at 300 °C at GHSV = 60,000 mL g−1 h−1 under dry and wet conditions (Fig. 9 ). Co3O4 presented a stable conversion of 1, 2-DCE except for a slight decline in the initial 30 min and maintained at about 40 % within 240 min. After 3 vol. % water was introduced, a visible decrease from 40 % to 30 % in 1, 2-DCE conversion occurred, and the formation of trichloroethane was also inhibited (Fig. S9). Generally, H2O molecules adsorbed on defect sites such as Co2+ and oxygen vacancies, thus dissociated into the OH- and H+. However, these defect sites were also considered to be the active sites for adsorbing and dissociating gaseous oxygen and 1, 2-DCE. So, the competitive adsorption was responsible for the decline in activity. On the other hand, the formed H+ could promote the removal of Cl species through the formation of HCl [54,58], which lead the low trichloroethane concentration and with the fact that Deacon Reaction over Co3O4 just accelerated at a temperature higher than 300 °C (TPSR, Fig. S6). After the water was turned off, the 1, 2-DCE conversion recovered and the selectivity to trichloroethane increased (Fig. S9). For supported RuOx catalysts, similar with Co3O4, both RuOx/Co3O4-HP and RuOx/Co3O4-IM also presented a slight decrease in 1, 2-DCE conversion in the initial time, from about 95 % to 87 % and 93 % to 83 %, respectively, and then remained stable within the next 240 min. The rapid deposition of Cl species on active sites led to the initial deactivation, which was confirmed by the fact that the H2-TPR results of used catalysts indicated that the reduction peaks shifted to a higher temperature (Fig. S10). However, with the addition of water vapor, a slight increase in 1, 2-DCE conversion was observed, which was completely different from Co3O4. This phenomenon was also found in the Van den Brink’s work [59], which was ascribed to the increase in mobility of active oxygen formed on the RuOx cluster or nanoparticles during the reaction (H2-TPR also confirmed the existence of RuOx cluster) [27]. When the water vapor turned off, the conversion of 1, 2-DCE returned to about 87 % and 83 %, respectively. Additionally, the behavior of trichloroethane formation including selectivity and generation time was different from Co3O4. For example, the trichloroethane selectivity was far lower than Co3O4 (Fig. S9), forming trichloroethane over RuOx/Co3O4-IM and RuOx/Co3O4-HP just occurred after about 90 min and 120 min. Characterizations of the used catalysts by XRD and N2 isotherms indicated that there were no significant modifications in lattice phase, crystalline size, specific surface area, and pore size distribution, indicating that both the crystal structure and bulk structure were stable under harsh conditions (Fig. S11). However, XPS results indicated that the deposit Cl species (2.35–2.45 atom. %, Table S2) was still observed on the used supported RuOx catalysts but lower than that of the used Co3O4 (2.93 %), which was ascribed to the high activity of RuOx based catalysts for Deacon Reaction. Additionally, the ratio of Co2+ to (Co2++Co3+) and Oβ/ (Oα +Oβ) also decreased, especially for Co3O4, which confirmed that the addition of RuOx species was favorable for maintaining the oxygen vacancies (Fig. S12 and Table S2). Fig. 9B further displayed the prolonged stability (50 h) of Co3O4 and RuOx/Co3O4-HP at 320 °C, carrying out by feeding the stream containing 1000 ppm 1, 2-DCE and 10 % O2 with a space velocity of 60,000 mL· g−1 h−1. For Co3O4, the conversion of 1, 2-DCE slightly declined in the initial 60 min and then maintained at about 45 % within 50 h. Meanwhile, the selectivity to trichloroethane was up to 18 %, and the accumulated Cl species were accounted for the formation of these polychlorinated by-products. For RuOx/Co3O4-HP, the conversion of 1, 2-DCE was maintained at about 100 % in the initial 60 min, and then a slight drop was observed, but the conversion of 1, 2-DCE was still higher than 92 % within 50 h. Moreover, the formation of trichloroethane was only observed after running 11 h, and the selectivity was lower than 5%. Briefly, the synthesized RuOx/Co3O4-HP showed a highly stable activity and less selectivity to trichloroethane for 1, 2-dichloroethane oxidation, and exceptional versatility for the removal of propane or toluene and their mixtures with 1, 2-DCE. Meanwhile, the beneficial effect of water vapor on catalytic oxidation performance of 1, 2-DCE was also confirmed. 4 Conclusions In this article, the plate-like Co(OH)(OCH3) was synthesized by a solvothermal method using methanol as solvent and then transferred into porous Co3O4 through the following calcination. Supported RuOx catalysts were prepared by three different methods using the synthesized Co3O4 as supports. Their physicochemical properties were characterized, and the potential application for eliminating CVOCs via catalytic oxidation in industrial exhaust gas was also investigated. The RuOx/Co3O4-HP catalyst prepared by the homogeneous precipitation method exhibited the best catalytic performance for 1, 2-DCE oxidation due to the most outstanding low-temperature reducibility, largest concentration of oxygen vacancies, and surface active oxygen species. The stable conversion of 1, 2-DCE could reach about 87 % over RuOx/Co3O4-HP with low selectivity to trichloroethane (< 5%) at 300 °C within 10 h. An inhibitory effect of water vapor in 1, 2-DCE conversion over Co3O4 was observed due to the possible competitive adsorption. However, the activity for 1, 2-DCE oxidation over supported RuOx catalysts was promoted in the presence of H2O. Moreover, RuOx/Co3O4-HP was also determined to be efficient for catalytic oxidation of other single pollutant or their mixtures, such as toluene or propane and the mixture of 1, 2-DCE. coredata.dc:description: Porous Co3O4 with high yield was synthesized through calcination from plate-like Co(OH)(OCH3). Then, a series of Co3O4 supported RuOx catalysts were prepared using three different loading methods, including homogeneous precipitation (HP), precipitation-deposition (DP), and wet impregnation (IM). Their physicochemical properties were investigated by various characterization techniques, and their performance for catalytic oxidation of 1, 2-dichloroethane (1, 2-DCE) was also evaluated. RuOx/Co3O4-HP possessed the most outstanding low-temperature reducibility, more oxygen vacancies, and surface active oxygen, correspondingly exhibited a better catalytic activity and lower selectivity of polychlorinated by-products. Moreover, RuOx/Co3O4-HP also presented an excellent performance for other types of hydrocarbons abatement. The stability test showed that the RuOx/Co3O4-HP showed highly stable activity for 1, 2-DCE oxidation, and the beneficial effect of water was further confirmed.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of preparation method on the performance of porous RuOx/Co3O4 catalysts for 1, 2-dichloroethane oxidation
